question.title: Debugging Java process using IntelliJ - connects to socket but not to target VM

node.contents: Now resolved - see end of question.

astNode.text: Now resolved - see end of question.

node.contents: I am attempting to debug a Java process with IntelliJ Community Edition's debugger. The socket is listening - but when I try to connect the debug process shows the following 'Connecting to the target VM, address: ':8003', transport: 'socket' It never makes the connection to the VM and I cannot debug.

astNode.text: I am attempting to debug a Java process with IntelliJ Community Edition's debugger. The socket is listening - but when I try to connect the debug process shows the following 'Connecting to the target VM, address: ':8003', transport: 'socket' It never makes the connection to the VM and I cannot debug.

node.contents: I have moved to a Windows 7 64 bit PC - on my old XP machine and could connect and debug this Java process (it's an app I build and maintain).

astNode.text: I have moved to a Windows 7 64 bit PC - on my old XP machine and could connect and debug this Java process (it's an app I build and maintain).

node.contents: It does not fail with the standard "Connection refused: Connect" error that you would get if no process was there to connect to. Netstat also shows the port is listening when the app is running.

astNode.text: It does not fail with the standard "Connection refused: Connect" error that you would get if no process was there to connect to. Netstat also shows the port is listening when the app is running.

node.contents: TCP 0.0.0.0:8003 :0 LISTENING

astNode.text: TCP 0.0.0.0:8003 :0 LISTENING

node.contents: Debug args for the app -Xrunjdwp:transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=n,address=8003 -Xdebug

astNode.text: Debug args for the app -Xrunjdwp:transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=n,address=8003 -Xdebug

node.contents: If I attempt to run the debug session from IntelliJ on a remote machine, I can connect to the process running on my local machine, and debug. If I run the Java app on a remote machine, and use IntelliJ on my local machine, I can debug. It is only if I run and debug on the same machine that it fails - unfortunately this is what I need to do almost all the time.

astNode.text: If I attempt to run the debug session from IntelliJ on a remote machine, I can connect to the process running on my local machine, and debug. If I run the Java app on a remote machine, and use IntelliJ on my local machine, I can debug. It is only if I run and debug on the same machine that it fails - unfortunately this is what I need to do almost all the time.

node.contents: The only similar issues I have found are from 2004, to do with file paths with spaces, and were NetBeans, not IntelliJ. I have rebuilt and rerun my app ensuring no spaces or underscores in the path, no joy.

astNode.text: The only similar issues I have found are from 2004, to do with file paths with spaces, and were NetBeans, not IntelliJ. I have rebuilt and rerun my app ensuring no spaces or underscores in the path, no joy.

node.contents: My intelliJ debug settings are to debug my local machine on socket, attach mode port 8003 - sorry as a new user I can't attach an image.

astNode.text: My intelliJ debug settings are to debug my local machine on socket, attach mode port 8003 - sorry as a new user I can't attach an image.

node.contents: Other things I have attempted:

astNode.text: Other things I have attempted:

node.contents:
• Changing JRE versions
  • Debugging using shared memory rather than socket transport
  • I have not re-installed IntelliJ - I am using the same build as my fellow devs (10.5 IC 107-105) who don't have this problem.
  • Changing the port the debugging process listens on (from 8003 to various other, unused according to netstat)
  • I have tried using PC name, IP Address and 'localhost' to refer to the PC in the debug settings.

astNode.text:
• Changing JRE versions
  • Debugging using shared memory rather than socket transport
  • I have not re-installed IntelliJ - I am using the same build as my fellow devs (10.5 IC 107-105) who don't have this problem.
  • Changing the port the debugging process listens on (from 8003 to various other, unused according to netstat)
  • I have tried using PC name, IP Address and 'localhost' to refer to the PC in the debug settings.

node.contents:
Stuck. Any help much appreciated.
Thanks Steve

astNode.text:
Stuck. Any help much appreciated.
Thanks Steve

node.contents: Resolved

astNode.text: Resolved

node.contents: Well, a day of failing to solve then I find the answer 20 mins after posting. An invalid JNI signature character, only picked up when debugging. Solved by adding this arg when debugging.

astNode.text: Well, a day of failing to solve then I find the answer 20 mins after posting. An invalid JNI signature character, only picked up when debugging. Solved by adding this arg when debugging.

node.contents: -Dcom.sun.xml.bind.v2.bytecode.ClassTailor.noOptimize=true

astNode.text: -Dcom.sun.xml.bind.v2.bytecode.ClassTailor.noOptimize=true

node.contents: http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=6547438

astNode.text: http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=6547438

node.contents: Thanks for the assistance. Still don't know why it would work when debugging remotely but not locally before.

astNode.text: Thanks for the assistance. Still don't know why it would work when debugging remotely but not locally before.

node.contents: Agree, try disabling the firewall temporarily and see if it helps.

astNode.text: Agree, try disabling the firewall temporarily and see if it helps.

node.contents: How would that affect shared memory? Steve says that it doesn't work also: `Debugging using shared memory rather than socket transport`.

astNode.text: How would that affect shared memory? Steve says that it doesn't work also: `Debugging using shared memory rather than socket transport`.

node.contents: No, can connect to that port - also can debug to that port from a remote machine

astNode.text: No, can connect to that port - also can debug to that port from a remote machine

node.contents: @CrazyCoder, good point.

astNode.text: @CrazyCoder, good point.

node.contents: It sounds like a strange firewall issue.

astNode.text: It sounds like a strange firewall issue.

node.contents: It appears that you should be able to try telnet localhost 8003 and it should fail. This means nothing can connect to your app on that port.

astNode.text: It appears that you should be able to try telnet localhost 8003 and it should fail. This means nothing can connect to your app on that port.

node.contents: EDIT: If shared memory does work either and you cannot connecft it via telnet, there is a problem with the way you are running the app.

astNode.text: EDIT: If shared memory does work either and you cannot connecft it via telnet, there is a problem with the way you are running the app.

node.contents: You will get this type of error if the application is not running.

astNode.text: You will get this type of error if the application is not running.
